message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Model Checking Algorithms for Markov Automata
Paper Abstract: Markov automata constitute a compositional modeling formalism spanning as special cases the models of discrete and continuous time Markov chains, as well as interactive Markov chains and probabilistic automata. This paper discusses the core algorithmic ingredients of a numerical model checking procedure for Markov automata with respect to a PCTL or CSL like temporal logic. The main challenge lies in the computation of time-bounded reachability probabilities, for which we provide a stable approximation scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Absorbing Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absorbing_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Discrete-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Stochastic matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_matrix"},{"title":"Markov kernel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_kernel"},{"title":"Markov property - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_property"},{"title":"Examples of Markov chains - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Examples_of_Markov_chains"},{"title":"Markovian arrival process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markovian_arrival_process"},{"title":"Continuous-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain Monte Carlo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain_Monte_Carlo"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about reachability probability in the context of Markov chains:

## Reachability in Markov Chains

Two states are said to communicate with each other if both are reachable from one another by a sequence of transitions that have positive probability.

### State Space Partitioning

A Markov chain's state space can be partitioned into communicating classes that describe which states are reachable from each other (in one transition or in many).

### Irreducibility

A key concept related to reachability is irreducibility. A Markov chain is said to be irreducible if its state space is a single communicating class; in other words, if it is possible to get to any state from any state. 

In the context of Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), a Markov chain is said to be irreducible if it is possible to reach any state from any other state in a finite number of steps with positive probability.

### Absorbing Chains

Another important application of reachability is in absorbing Markov chains. An absorbing Markov chain is a Markov chain in which every state can reach an absorbing state.

These concepts are fundamental to analyzing the long-term behavior and properties of Markov processes, including whether certain states are accessible and how probability distributions evolve over time.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Markov chain discrete time"

Links: [{"title":"Discrete-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Continuous-time Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous-time_Markov_chain"},{"title":"Markov renewal process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_renewal_process"},{"title":"Hidden Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidden_Markov_model"},{"title":"Deterioration modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deterioration_modeling"},{"title":"Kolmogorov equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov_equations_(continuous-time_Markov_chains)"},{"title":"Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Uniformization (probability theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniformization_(probability_theory)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about discrete-time Markov chains:

## Definition

A discrete-time Markov chain (DTMC) is a sequence of random variables, known as a stochastic process, in which the value of the next variable depends only on the value of the current variable, and not any variables in the past.

## Key Characteristics

The Markov property states that the conditional probability distribution for the system at the next step (and in fact at all future steps) depends only on the current state of the system, and not additionally on the state of the system at previous steps.(no content)The steps are often thought of as moments in time, but they can equally well refer to physical distance or any other discrete measurement.

## Description and Analysis

A Markov chain can be described by a stochastic matrix, which lists the probabilities of moving to each state from any individual state. From this matrix, the probability of being in a particular state n steps in the future can be calculated.

## State Classification

Each state can be described as transient or recurrent, depending on the probability of the chain ever returning to that state.(no content)A Markov chain's state space can be partitioned into communicating classes that describe which states are reachable from each other (in one transition or in many).

## Additional Properties

Markov chains can have properties including periodicity, reversibility and stationarity.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Markov automata"

Links: [{"title":"Probabilistic automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_automaton"},{"title":"Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Stochastic cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Markov chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_chain"},{"title":"Finite-state machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_machine"},{"title":"Quantum finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Learning automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_Automata"},{"title":"Graph dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_dynamical_system"},{"title":"Automata-based programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automata-Based_Programming"},{"title":"Examples of Markov chains - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Examples_of_Markov_chains"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Markov automata:

## Overview

While the search results don't directly discuss "Markov automata" as a specific named concept, they reveal several closely related topics:

**Related Concepts:**

1. **Probabilistic Automata**: The probabilistic automaton (PA) is a generalization of the nondeterministic finite automaton; it includes the probability of a given transition into the transition function, turning it into a transition matrix.(no content)The probabilistic automaton also generalizes the concepts of a Markov chain and of a subshift of finite type.

2. **Stochastic Automata**: The states of a stochastic automaton correspond to the states of a "discrete-state discrete-parameter Markov process". At each time step t = 0,1,2,3,..., the automaton reads an input from its environment, updates P(t) to P(t + 1) by A, randomly chooses a successor state according to the probabilities P(t + 1) and outputs the corresponding action.

3. **Connection to Markov Chains**: A finite-state machine can be used as a representation of a Markov chain. Assuming a sequence of independent and identically distributed input signals, if the machine is in state y at time n, then the probability that it moves to state x at time n + 1 depends only on the current state.

The term "Markov automata" typically refers to these probabilistic or stochastic automata that incorporate Markovian properties, where transitions are probabilistic and depend only on the current state.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about continuous time Markov chains:

## Definition

A continuous-time Markov chain (CTMC) is a continuous stochastic process in which, for each state, the process will change state according to an exponential random variable and then move to a different state as specified by the probabilities of a stochastic matrix.

## Key Characteristics

A continuous-time Markov chain is like a discrete-time Markov chain, but it moves states continuously through time rather than as discrete time steps.(no content)A CTMC satisfies the Markov property, that its behavior depends only on its current state and not on its past behavior, due to the memorylessness of the exponential distribution and of discrete-time Markov chains.

## Transition-Rate Matrix

A transition-rate matrix (also known as a Q-matrix, intensity matrix, or infinitesimal generator matrix) is an array of numbers describing the instantaneous rate at which a continuous-time Markov chain transitions between states.

## Important Theoretical Concepts

Kolmogorov's criterion states that the necessary and sufficient condition for a process to be reversible is that the product of transition rates around a closed loop must be the same in both directions.(no content)One method of finding the stationary probability distribution, π, of an ergodic continuous-time Markov chain, Q, is by first finding its embedded Markov chain (EMC).

## Historical Development

Andrey Kolmogorov developed in a 1931 paper a large part of the early theory of continuous-time Markov processes.

Links: [{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"List of model checking tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_model_checking_tools"},{"title":"Principles of Model Checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principles_of_Model_Checking"},{"title":"SPIN model checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SPIN_model_checker"},{"title":"Informal methods of validation and verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Informal_methods_of_validation_and_verification"},{"title":"Category:Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Model_checking"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Program analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Program_analysis"},{"title":"Streaming conformance checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Streaming_conformance_checking"},{"title":"Model-based testing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_based_testing"}]

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about model checking algorithms:

## Overview

Model checking is a method for checking whether a finite-state model of a system meets a given specification. Model checking is the process of describing requirements in mathematical language, and automating proofs that the model satisfies the requirements, or discovery of counterexamples if the model is faulty.

## Key Applications

Model checking is typically associated with hardware or software systems, where the specification contains liveness requirements (such as avoidance of livelock) as well as safety requirements (such as avoidance of states representing a system crash). Model checking is most often applied to hardware designs.

## The State Explosion Problem

A major challenge in model checking is the state explosion problem. Model-checking tools face a combinatorial blow up of the state-space, commonly known as the state explosion problem, that must be addressed to solve most real-world problems.

## Algorithm Approaches

To address the state explosion problem, several approaches exist:

1. **Symbolic Algorithms**: Symbolic algorithms avoid ever explicitly constructing the graph for the FSM; instead, they represent the graph implicitly using a formula in quantified propositional logic. The use of binary decision diagrams (BDDs) was made popular by the work of Ken McMillan, as well as of Olivier Coudert and Jean-Christophe Madre, and the development of open-source BDD manipulation libraries such as CUDD and BuDDy.

2. **Bounded Model Checking**: Bounded model-checking algorithms unroll the FSM for a fixed number of steps, or fewer steps. This typically involves encoding the restricted model as an instance of SAT.

## Specification Languages

An important class of model-checking methods has been developed for checking models of hardware and software designs where the specification is given by a temporal logic formula. Common specification languages include Linear Temporal Logic (LTL) and Computation Tree Logic (CTL).

Rabin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_O._Rabin"},{"title":"Quantum finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_finite_automaton"},{"title":"Nondeterministic finite automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nondeterministic_Finite_Automaton"},{"title":"Cellular automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellular_automaton"},{"title":"Weighted automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weighted_automaton"},{"title":"Graph dynamical system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_dynamical_system"},{"title":"Finite-state transducer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite-state_transducer"},{"title":"Probabilistic Turing machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_Turing_machine"}]

Here are the search results for "probabilistic automata":

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, the probabilistic automaton (PA) is a generalization of the nondeterministic finite automaton; it includes the probability of a given transition into the transition function, turning it into a transition matrix.

## Languages and Properties

The set of languages recognized by probabilistic automata are called stochastic languages. They include the regular languages as a subset.(no content)Every regular language is stochastic, and more strongly, every regular language is η-stochastic.

## Historical Background

In 1960, Michael O. Rabin introduced probabilistic automata at Bell Labs that employ coin tosses in order to decide which state transitions to take. He showed examples of regular languages that required a very large number of states, but for which you get an exponential reduction of the number of states with probabilistic automata.

## Relationship to Markov Chains

Since each transition is (essentially) independent of the previous (if we disregard the distinction between accepted and rejected languages), the PFA essentially becomes a kind of Markov chain.

## Related Concepts

An example of such a generalization is the quantum finite automaton; here, the automaton state is represented by a point in complex projective space, while the transition matrices are a fixed set chosen from the unitary group.

Here are the search results for "probabilistic automata":

## Definition

In mathematics and computer science, the probabilistic automaton (PA) is a generalization of the nondeterministic finite automaton; it includes the probability of a given transition into the transition function, turning it into a transition matrix.

## Languages and Properties

The set of languages recognized by probabilistic automata are called stochastic languages. They include the regular languages as a subset.(no content)Every regular language is stochastic, and more strongly, every regular language is η-stochastic.

## Historical Background

In 1960, Michael O. Rabin introduced probabilistic automata at Bell Labs that employ coin tosses in order to decide which state transitions to take. He showed examples of regular languages that required a very large number of states, but for which you get an exponential reduction of the number of states with probabilistic automata.

## Relationship to Markov Chains

Since each transition is (essentially) independent of the previous (if we disregard the distinction between accepted and rejected languages), the PFA essentially becomes a kind of Markov chain.

## Related Concepts

An example of such a generalization is the quantum finite automaton; here, the automaton state is represented by a point in complex projective space, while the transition matrices are a fixed set chosen from the unitary group.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of temporal logic model checking:

## Overview

Model checking is a method for checking whether a finite-state model of a system meets a given specification. Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware or software systems.

## Temporal Logic Basics

Temporal logic is any system of rules and symbolism for representing, and reasoning about, propositions qualified in terms of time (for example, "I am always hungry", "I will eventually be hungry", or "I will be hungry until I eat something").

There aretwo main approaches:
- Linear-time logics are restricted to reasoning about a single timeline
- Branching-time logics can reason about multiple timelines, which permits treatment of environments that may act unpredictably

## Key Temporal Logic Types

**Linear Temporal Logic (LTL):** Linear temporal logic is a modal temporal logic with modalities referring to time. In LTL, one can encode formulae about the future of paths, e.g., a condition will eventually be true, a condition will be true until another fact becomes true, etc.

**Computation Tree Logic (CTL):** Because CTL is more computationally efficient to model check, it has become more common in industrial use, and many of the most successful model-checking tools use CTL as a specification language.

**CTL*:** CTL* is a superset of computational tree logic (CTL) and linear temporal logic (LTL). It freely combines path quantifiers and temporal operators.

## Properties Expressed

The specification typically contains liveness requirements (such as avoidance of livelock) as well as safety requirements (such as avoidance of states representing a system crash).

## Applications

Model checking is most often applied to hardware designs, though model-checking tools have been extended to deal with real-time and limited forms of hybrid systems.

Links: [{"title":"Probabilistic CTL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_CTL"},{"title":"Computation tree logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computation_tree_logic"},{"title":"Timed propositional temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TPTL"},{"title":"Temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_logic"},{"title":"Linear temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_Temporal_Logic"},{"title":"Alternating-time temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternating-time_Temporal_Logic"},{"title":"CTL* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CTL*"},{"title":"TLA+ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TLA+"},{"title":"Temporal logic of actions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_logic_of_actions"},{"title":"Metric temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_temporal_logic"}]

## Overview of PCTL Temporal Logic

Probabilistic Computation Tree Logic (PCTL) is an extension of computation tree logic (CTL) that allows for probabilistic quantification of described properties.(no content)It has been defined in the paper by Hansson and Jonsson.

### Purpose and Applications

PCTL is a useful logic for stating soft deadline properties, such as "after a request for a service, there is at least a 98% probability that the service will be carried out within 2 seconds".(no content)Like CTL's suitability for model-checking, PCTL extension is widely used as a property specification language for probabilistic model checkers.

### Semantics

Formulas of PCTL are interpreted over discrete Markov chains. This makes it particularly useful for systems where probabilistic behavior needs to be specified and verified.

PCTL essentially combines the branching-time temporal logic capabilities of CTL with probabilistic reasoning, allowing specifications of properties that must hold with certain probability thresholds.

Based on the search results, I found information about CSL, though it appears the results primarily focus on one particular meaning of the acronym:

## CSL: Continuous Spontaneous Localization

The continuous spontaneous localization (CSL) model is a spontaneous collapse model in quantum mechanics, proposed in 1989 by Philip Pearle and finalized in 1990 by Gian Carlo Ghirardi, Philip Pearle and Alberto Rimini.(no content)The Schrödinger equation is supplemented with a nonlinear and stochastic diffusion process driven by a suitably chosen universal noise coupled to the mass-density of the system, which counteracts the quantum spread of the wave function.

### Key Characteristics

The CSL model describes the collapse of the wave function as occurring continuously in time, in contrast to the Ghirardi-Rimini-Weber model.(no content)The model does not significantly alter the dynamics of microscopic systems, while it becomes strong for macroscopic objects: the amplification mechanism ensures this scaling.

**Note:** The search results do not appear to contain information about "CSL continuous stochastic logic" as a distinct concept in formal logic or specification. If you're looking for information about CSL in the context of formal verification or model checking (rather than quantum mechanics), please let me know and I can search again.

Based on the search results, I found information about CSL, though it appears the results primarily focus on one particular meaning of the acronym:

## CSL: Continuous Spontaneous Localization

The continuous spontaneous localization (CSL) model is a spontaneous collapse model in quantum mechanics, proposed in 1989 by Philip Pearle and finalized in 1990 by Gian Carlo Ghirardi, Philip Pearle and Alberto Rimini.(no content)The Schrödinger equation is supplemented with a nonlinear and stochastic diffusion process driven by a suitably chosen universal noise coupled to the mass-density of the system, which counteracts the quantum spread of the wave function.

### Key Characteristics

The CSL model describes the collapse of the wave function as occurring continuously in time, in contrast to the Ghirardi-Rimini-Weber model.(no content)The model does not significantly alter the dynamics of microscopic systems, while it becomes strong for macroscopic objects: the amplification mechanism ensures this scaling.

**Note:** The search results do not appear to contain information about "CSL continuous stochastic logic" as a distinct concept in formal logic or specification. If you're looking for information about CSL in the context of formal verification or model checking (rather than quantum mechanics), please let me know and I can search again.

I've found comprehensive information about approximation schemes and numerical algorithms. Here are the key findings from the search results:

## Approximation Schemes

In computer science (particularly algorithmics), a polynomial-time approximation scheme (PTAS) is a type of approximation algorithm for optimization problems (most often, NP-hard optimization problems).(no content)A PTAS is an algorithm which takes an instance of an optimization problem and a parameter ε > 0 and produces a solution that is within a factor 1 + ε of being optimal (or 1 – ε for maximization problems).(no content)A more restrictive and practically useful variant is the fully polynomial-time approximation scheme or FPTAS, which requires the algorithm to be polynomial in both the problem size n and 1/ε.

## Approximation Algorithms

In computer science and operations research, approximation algorithms are efficient algorithms that find approximate solutions to optimization problems (in particular NP-hard problems) with provable guarantees on the distance of the returned solution to the optimal one.

## Numerical Algorithms

Various numerical algorithms exist for different purposes:

- **Differential Equations**: The Euler method is a first-order numerical procedure for solving ordinary differential equations (ODEs) with a given initial value. It is the most basic explicit method for numerical integration of ordinary differential equations and is the simplest Runge–Kutta method.

- **Root Finding**: The Newton–Raphson method, also known simply as Newton's method, is a root-finding algorithm which produces successively better approximations to the roots (or zeroes) of a real-valued function.

- **Function Approximation**: For known target functions, approximation theory is the branch of numerical analysis that investigates how certain known functions can be approximated by a specific class of functions (for example, polynomials or rational functions) that often have desirable properties.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about interactive Markov chains:

## Interactive Markov Chains

Markov chains are used in systems which use a Markov model to react interactively to music input. This is one of the main applications of interactive Markov chains mentioned in the literature.

Additionally, there's a concept called "interacting Markov chain Monte Carlo" (MCMC), which differs from basic interactive systems. Any Markov chain Monte Carlo sampler can be turned into an interacting Markov chain Monte Carlo sampler, which can be interpreted as a way to run in parallel a sequence of Markov chain Monte Carlo samplers.(no content)Interacting MCMC methodologies are a class of mean-field particle methods for obtaining random samples from a sequence of probability distributions with an increasing level of sampling complexity.

The search results suggest two main meanings of "interactive" in the context of Markov chains:
1. **Systems that react to input** (like music generation systems that respond to user input)
2. **Parallel computational methods** (where multiple Markov chain samplers interact with each other in statistical computations)

If you're looking for more specific information about interactive Markov chains, could you clarify whether you're interested in applications, mathematical theory, or implementation details?

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed all tasks. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✓

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution** - The paper proposes new algorithmic methods for model checking Markov automata, specifically a stable approximation scheme for computing time-bounded reachability probabilities.

**Triples Extracted and Verified**: 8 triples total

**Key Findings**:
- **6 Concept triples** (Uses): Markov chain, Discrete-time Markov chain, Continuous-time Markov chain, Probabilistic automaton, Probabilistic CTL, Temporal logic
- **2 Method triples**: Model checking (Uses) and Approximation algorithm (Proposes)

**Validation**: All checks passed successfully! The JSON file has been properly formatted with correct Wikipedia URLs, entity types, and relevance descriptions.

The triples correctly capture the paper's foundation in existing stochastic modeling formalisms while highlighting the novel contribution of the approximation scheme for solving the time-bounded reachability probability problem.
